Developing a Disaster Risk Financing Capability 
(Financed by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction)

GLOSSARY 
 
Catastrophe bond  –  A security that transfers defined catastrophe risks to investors via a 
  bond (a debt instrument issued to raise capital.) The principal of the 
bond is used to pay off losses in the event of a specified catastrophe.
 
Climate change  –  Adjustment in natural or human systems in response to actual or 
adaptation  expected climatic stimuli or their effects which moderates harm or 
exploits beneficial opportunities.  
 
Disaster  –  A serious disruption to the functioning of a community or a society, 
  causing widespread human, economic, or environmental losses that 
exceed the ability of the affected community or society to cope using 
its own resources. 
 
Disaster risk  –  The  application  of  financial  instruments  to  anticipate,  plan  for, 
finance  reduce, and transfer disaster risks before disasters occur. 
 
Disaster risk  –  The  systematic  process  of  using  administrative  decisions, 
management  organizations,  operational  skills,  and  capacities  to  implement 
  policies, strategies, and coping capacities of a society to lessen the 
  impacts of natural hazards and related disasters.

Disaster risk  –  A computerized model that uses a set of simulated disaster events to 
model  estimate losses that may arise from a disaster. 
   
Disaster risk  –  A series of interconnected actions to minimize disaster vulnerability 
reduction  by avoiding (prevention) or limiting (mitigation and preparedness) the 
adverse effects of hazards within the broad context of sustainable 
development. 
 
Exposure  –  The sum total of human life, economic activities, and assets at risk of 
loss if a hazard leads to a disaster. Or, in the context of an insurance 
contract, the total of insured assets (or the sum insured) at risk of 
loss resulting from the occurrence of the event insured against at any 
one time. 
 
Hazard  –  A  potentially  damaging  physical  event,  phenomenon,  or  human 
  activity that may cause loss of life, injury, property damage, social 
and economic disruption, or environmental degradation. 
 
Integrated disaster  –  As used in this report, integrated disaster risk management means 
risk  systematic  activities  that  aim  to  avoid,  lessen,  or  transfer  the 
management  potential  adverse  effects  of  all  hazards,  specifically  through  the 
  integration of climate change adaptation, disaster risk finance, and 
disaster risk reduction measures.  
 
Insurance-linked  –  Traded  securities  derived  from  insurance  instruments  such  as 
securities  catastrophe bonds. 
Relief or  –  The terms are used interchangeably in the literature to mean the 
response  provision of assistance or intervention during or immediately after a 
disaster to meet the life preservation and basic subsistence needs of 
those affected. Duration can be immediate, short-term, or extended. 
 
Risk assessment  –  A  methodology  to  determine  the  nature  and  extent  of  risk  by 
analyzing potential hazards and evaluating conditions of vulnerability 
that pose a potential threat or harm to people, property, livelihoods, 
and the environment on which they depend. 
 
Risk transfer  –  The  contractual  process  whereby  the  burden  of  financial  loss  is 
shifted to another party via insurance or another financing instrument 
in return for the payment of a premium. 
 
Vulnerability  –  Conditions  determined  by  physical,  social,  economic,  and 
environmental  factors  that  increase  community  susceptibility  to 
hazard impact.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The impacts of disasters due to natural hazards are intensified by the vulnerability in  
developing countries, leading to patterns of impact that are often more frequent and more 
extensive than those experienced by developed nations.1 Meteorological variations and extreme 
weather events brought on by climate change seem destined to add to the adverse impacts of 
these natural calamities in Asia and the Pacific. Geophysical catastrophes, while less frequent, 
are especially destructive in terms of lives lost and economic dislocation. The fact that natural 
hazards  pose  a  particularly  great  threat  to  urban  areas  raises  the  need  for  special  risk 
assessment techniques and tools. To be effective, disaster risk management (DRM) must shift 
from its current focus on post-disaster recovery and reconstruction toward an approach that 
balances  proactive  risk  management  and  disaster  risk  finance  (DRF)  with  traditional  post-
disaster aid.  
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) was the first multilateral development bank (MDB) 
to have a dedicated disaster policy.2 ADB’s long commitment to DRM is reinforced in Strategy 
2020 with DRM, climate change adaptation (CCA), and risk financing identified as core areas of 
operations.3 Between 1987 and 2009, ADB contributed $9.69 billion to DRM activities through 
412 projects. ADB has also been studying opportunities for DRF within the region since 2005 
and co-sponsored, with Japan’s Ministry of Finance, the 2008 Tokyo Conference on Natural 
Catastrophe Risk Insurance Mechanisms for Asia and the Pacific.4 
 
3.  DRF employs financial instruments to anticipate and plan for disasters and reduce and 
transfer disaster risks. As developed by ADB and other MDBs, DRF includes insurance, disaster 
budgeting and reserving, credit products, and capital market instruments to transfer disaster risk. 
The importance of DRF is reflected in ADB’s strategic climate change priorities.5  These call for 
a focus on risk management through DRF and disaster risk reduction (DRR) investments as 
part of new solutions to reduce the impact of total climate risk due to both existing climate 
vulnerability and climate change.  
 
4.  ADB is preparing to launch an integrated disaster risk management (IDRM) effort based 
on three pillars: (i) DRF, (ii) DRR, and (iii) CCA. This TA supports initiatives in these areas to 
develop capacity in Indonesia and the Philippines to manage disaster risks at the national and 
city levels more systematically, thereby expanding DRM capacity, reducing potential disaster 
impacts, and enhancing climate resilience6 (Appendix 1). 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  Between 1975 and 2007, 37% of the world's recorded disasters due to natural hazards 
occurred in Asia, accounting for 57% of overall deaths, 89% of the population affected, and 45% 
of property and infrastructure damage.7 More recent data show that this concentration was also 
pronounced in 2009, when 43% of the disasters worldwide happened in Asia, which was also

home to 62% of all disaster victims globally.8 The fact that 77% of all disasters in Asia during 
1975–2007 were weather-related suggests that the onset of climate change will make the 
development of comprehensive climate risk management strategies even more important. 9 The 
Philippines,  ranking  8th  worldwide  in  terms  of  disaster  incidence  and  human  impact,  and 
Indonesia, ranking 12th, are particularly disaster prone.10  
 
6.  Several factors favor an urban focus for IDRM. Asia’s cities are particularly vulnerable to 
both  geophysical  and  weather-related  natural  hazards  and  have  distinct  DRM  issues  and 
challenges. Given Asia’s large and growing urban population and the extent to which economic 
activity is increasingly urban-based, urban disaster management has become more urgent. 
MDBs and international aid organizations have so far focused largely on rural and national 
disaster management, creating the need to consider the unique vulnerabilities, hazards, and 
exposures that Asia’s cities manifest.  
 
7.  Like the rest of the region, Indonesia and the Philippines have traditionally relied on 
post-disaster  assistance.  This  approach  carries  substantial  risks  in  timing,  targeting,  and 
opportunity costs.11 Low insurance penetration has raised the financial cost of past natural 
disasters in Asia because disaster losses have been internalized by the economy and not 
spread to those better able to absorb them.12 The World Bank has estimated that the use of 
DRM tools and mechanisms, including insurance, can reduce the economic impacts of a natural 
disaster by $7 for every $1 spent.13 
 
8.  Widespread efforts by the international community to encourage the mainstreaming of 
DRM in development policy and programs were reflected in the Hyogo Framework for Action 
(HFA)14 in 2005. The HFA’s main aim is to integrate DRM into development initiatives and 
emphasize proactive measures like DRR and DRF. The HFA’s 10-year plan recognized that 
post-disaster funding is often poorly targeted, untimely, and unpredictable. Development of 
commercial markets to help manage, insure, and underwrite catastrophe risk has enhanced the 
effectiveness of DRM and DRF instruments and mechanisms. Private sector participants in this 
market have developed new approaches to financing and spreading these risks, including 
reinsurance  products  and  capital  market  solutions  supported  by  insurance-linked  security 
trading platforms.15 Commercial market participants, such as the Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance 
Group, Munich Re, and Swiss Re have made clear they are prepared to partner with ADB to 
develop DRF solutions to disaster risk in the Asia and Pacific region. A vital part of ADB’s IDRM 
efforts  will  be  to  develop  effective  public–private  partnerships  (PPPs)  to  create  innovative 
disaster risk financing solutions for developing member countries (DMCs).  
 
9.  The World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) have been developing 
DRF expertise and resources for a number of years, the World Bank since the late 1990s and 
IDB since 2004. They have reoriented member country disaster programs away from post-event 
funding and made risk financing a central pillar. The World Bank’s Caribbean disaster finance 
initiative16 provides  hurricane  and  earthquake  protection  to  16  member  countries  from  a

a Pacific region disaster reserve fund17 that will provide a reserve structure, fund management,

10.  The IDB has taken a different course, stressing the creation of systematic, multifaceted 
risk management programs at the national level that are tailored to each country. To link DRM 
investments  to  a  national  DRM  strategy,  the  IDB  model  has  integrated  a  variety  of  DRR 
investments (e.g., disaster awareness programs, assistance with building code compliance, and 
strengthened national regulatory environments) with the DRF efforts.  
 
11.  ADB has chosen to develop a disaster management strategy closely associated with this 
IDB model. Building on the three pillars of DRF, DRR, and CCA, ADB’s IDRM approach will 
seek to develop systematic DRM programs at national and city levels in DMCs to significantly 
enhance their capacity to manage disaster risk. The IDRM framework will involve an element of 
conditionality that will provide incentives to DMCs to adopt a holistic approach to DRM to reduce 
the impacts of disasters and enhance climate resilience. 
 
12.  Climate risk is a vital component of the IDRM framework due to the strong relationship 
between CCA and DRM. An increase in extreme meteorological events, resulting in disastrous 
consequences, is an important manifestation of climate change. Drought, flooding, landslides, 
and coastal erosion are among the risks raised by climate change and these hazards must be 
incorporated in any comprehensive IDRM framework. This is particularly true for major urban 
areas in Indonesia and the Philippines that face serious threats from both climate change and 
other natural hazards.  
 
13.  This TA will be complemented by additional activities under a climate change cluster TA 
that will focus on risk profiling and testing of DRF solutions in a third project in urban areas in 
Viet Nam that face primarily hydrometeorological risks. While that project will be managed as a 
separate component within a broader climate change cluster TA and will explore risk factors and 
risk financing obstacles that may be encountered in addressing climate change scenarios, it will 
also feed into this TA for Indonesia and Philippines.  
 
14.  Demand by DMCs for more DRM tools and programs is partially offset by their concern 
that  spending  on  DRM  measures  before  a  disaster  could  jeopardize  assistance  for 
reconstruction and rehabilitation after one occurs. This concern shows that a DMC focus on 
post-disaster funding continues and highlights the difficulty of winning DMC acceptance of 
upfront investment in risk management even though this can reduce the economic impacts of a 
natural disaster by $7 for every $1 spent (footnote 13). To help DMC governments realize the 
potential gains from better DRM, ADB will gradually incorporate IDRM programs that (i) increase 
DMC awareness of the benefits of IDRM policies, (ii) illustrate the impact of IDRM via DRF 
projects, (iii) demonstrate the utility of risk models to support DRF, and (iv) develop DMC 
capacity to build their own DRM institutions and programs.

III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
15.  The impact of the TA will be greater DRM capacity, reduced disaster impacts over time, 
and enhanced climate resilience. The outcome will be strengthened national and urban capacity 
in DRF in the context of IDRM in Indonesia and Philippines. 
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
16.  The TA aims to establish an IDRM framework building on three areas simultaneously: 
DRF, DRR, and CCA. These key areas will be supported by the development of projects, each 
of which will advance the use of finance instruments, link the financing to investments in risk 
reduction, and promote climate change adaptation. The project activities will be organized 
around four outputs to achieve the outcome outlined above: (i) risk profiling and risk modeling, 
(ii)  product  design  and  implementation  of  DRF  projects,  (iii)  awareness  raising    through 
consultation, training, and dissemination and (iv) establishment of a project management unit to 
implement the TA.  
 
17.  Risk profiling and risk modeling. The TA will fund the development of disaster risk 
profiles based on available hazard, exposure, and loss data. Two project cities each will be 
selected in Indonesia and the Philippines based on the risk profiling and consultations with the 
governments  on  DRM  priorities.  The  risk  profiling  data  will  also  be  important  for  the 
development  of  disaster  risk  models  to  define  the  hazards,  locations,  and  the  severity  of 
disaster events that will trigger financing under the DRF program. Quality models are essential 
to structure successful DRF projects and to build disaster databases to support further DMC 
and regional disaster research. 
 
18.  Product design and implementation of DRF projects. Based on this risk analysis, the 
TA will support the exploration of opportunities and the technical feasibility of developing DRF 
solutions for major urban areas in Indonesia and the Philippines. The feasibility study will narrow 
available DRF options to those that reflect DMC demand, are technically feasible, and can be 
supported in commercial markets, if needed. Assistance will be provided to fully develop, design, 
and implement DRF projects in each project city. Stakeholder workshops will be held to solicit 
input and cities will be identified based on demand, feasibility, availability of hazard data, and 
commercial  market  acceptance,  if  needed.  Design  options  will  then  be  considered  and 
implemented  in  response  to  DMC  requirements  and  technical  considerations.  Preliminary 
scoping activities have suggested options for potential DRF products: (i) insurance programs; (ii) 
sovereign  disaster  liquidity  insurance;  (iii)  standby  emergency  credit  programs;  (iv)  a 
catastrophe bond program; or (v) an innovative combination of these approaches (e.g., using a 
short-term  emergency  loan  that  would  be  repaid  under  indemnity  insurance  coverage). 
Ultimately, ADB’s aim is to build on the TA results to support national and local governments to 
apply the IDRM framework throughout urban areas in Indonesia, the Philippines, and other 
DMCs. 
 
19.  Significant  opportunities  will  exist  for  governments  and  ADB  to  collaborate  with 
commercial market participants during the design and implementation of the DRF projects and 
under the IDRM framework afterwards. Building on lessons from this collaboration, the TA will 
also support development of effective PPP models for DRF that leverage resources and skills to 
deliver innovative financial solutions to DMCs that neither governments nor the commercial 
market  could  produce  entirely  on  their  own.  Examples  include  risk  modeling,  insurance 
structuring and placement, reinsurance, and ongoing capital market support. 
 
20.  Awareness raising through consultation, training, and dissemination. Throughout 
the inception and implementation of the TA, planning workshops and training courses will be

5
held to engage a wide range of stakeholders coming from national and local government 
agencies, civil society organizations, academic institutions, and the private sector. The results of 
the TA will also be disseminated widely to stakeholders in Indonesia and the Philippines as well 
as elsewhere in Asia and the Pacific through ADB reports, regional conferences, and other fora 
to keep the public informed and to mobilize support for improved disaster risk management 
 
18.  Establishment of a project management unit to implement the TA. To oversee the 
design and implementation of TA activities, project teams will be established that bring together 
key staff from all related agencies within the national and local governments. Engagement of 
civil society organizations and the private sector will also be encouraged through consultation 
and partnering activities. 
 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
22.  The regional policy and advisory TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000. The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
23.  The proposed TA will be implemented over a period of 36 months. ADB, through the 
Public  Management,  Governance,  and  Participation  Division  within  the  Regional  and 
Sustainable Development Department, will be the executing agency. The Public Management, 
Governance, and Participation Division will manage the TA in close coordination with ADB’s 
Southeast  Asia  Department  and  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department’s 
Climate Change Program Coordination Unit, the Environment and Safeguards Division, and the 
Sustainable Infrastructure Division. The National Agency for Disaster Management in Indonesia 
and  the  National  Disaster  Risk  Reduction  and  Management  Council  of  the  Office  of  Civil 
Defense in the Philippines will act as the implementing agencies. Working in their respective 
countries, they will lead engagement with relevant government agencies, follow the progress of 
the TA, identify opportunities to expand IDRM activities within the context of ongoing urban 
development, promote lessons and insights from the project to other urban areas, provide 
assistance and inputs to support project requirements, and coordinate local logistics. 
 
24.  The  TA  will  utilize  115  person-months  of  consultancy  inputs  to  be  provided  by  7 
international consultants (47 person-months) and 8 national consultants (68 person-months). All 
but one of the consultants will be engaged through a firm, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Given the importance, 
complexity, and impact of the project, the quality- and cost-based selection method, based on a 
quality-to-cost ratio of 80:20, and simplified technical proposals will be used. ADB will directly 
engage an international consultant as project coordinator on an individual basis for 15 person-
months in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. Disbursements under 
the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for consultants is in 
Appendix 3. Activities funded by this TA are subject to the formal review and approval of the 
governments and ADB. The TA is expected to be implemented from May 2011 to May 2014.

Key sub-activities

(ii)  Identify gap areas and design and data gathering activities to address

1.2.  Analyze  risks  and  develop  risk  models  for  DRF  projects  (January  –

Key sub-activities 
(i)  Review hazard, exposure, and historical loss data that are applicable 
and available for the DMC candidates in order to identify gaps  
(ii)  For participating urban areas, develop (i) stochastic data defining 
natural hazards, addressing the severity and frequency of the 
potential events; (ii) exposure data based on DMC requirements and 
specific hazards; (iii) vulnerability data to determine the extent to 
which covered assets are at risk, and (iv) a financial loss model that 
predicts the impact of likely natural disasters 
(iii) Analyze basis risk associated with project design and modeling 
 
Output 2.  Two DRF projects completed in each country as illustration of 
feasibility of DRF as a DRM solution

2.2.  Develop PPP strategy linking IDRM (September 2011 – February 2012) 
2.3.  Design and plan DRF project interventions (September 2011 – July 2012) 
Key sub-activities 
(i)  Conduct stakeholder workshops at national and city levels  
(ii)  Study relative feasibility of DRF transaction opportunities in terms of

Appendix 3  11 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  International  specialists  will  be  recruited  to  work  as  consultants  for  the  technical 
assistance (TA) for Developing a Disaster Risk Financing Capability and to collaborate with and 
be guided by staff from the Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD) and 
the Office of Cofinancing Operations of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). Acting under the 
primary direction of RSDD and coordinated by a lead project coordinator consultant, a specialist 
consultant firm(s) will design and execute an entry strategy for ADB into disaster risk finance 
(DRF), leading to the design and implementation of two DRF projects. The entry strategy will 
identify  opportunities  for  the  application  of  DRF  solutions  in  developing  member  countries 
(DMCs) throughout the region and for potential synergies from ADB involvement. The strategy 
will also link new financing techniques relating to natural disasters closely to climate change 
adaptation (CCA) initiatives that seek to reduce the risks of natural disasters from climate 
change.  
 
A.  Project Coordination (1 international, 15 person-months, intermittent) 
 
2.  The project coordinator will take overall responsibility for coordinating and managing the 
work product of the consultant firm(s) and their participation in executing the ADB entry strategy, 
including the close coordination with ADB CCA specialists. The project coordinator will have 
specialist  knowledge  of  DRF  products,  markets,  and  participants,  as  well  as  a  detailed 
understanding of public sector (multilateral development bank) involvement in DRF and how the 
private sector has interfaced with the public sector. The project coordinator will also have a 
detailed knowledge of ADB, its operations, resources, and procedures. Additional consulting 
time for the project coordinator is budgeted under a related TA project for Viet Nam. As part of 
his or her responsibilities, the project coordinator will  
 
(i)  provide technical advice and support to the RSDD team and the implementing 
agencies; 
(ii)  develop and coordinate consultant firm outputs per established milestones; 
(iii)  develop and coordinate national project facilitator inputs; 
(iv)  coordinate linkages between this TA project and a second disaster risk financing 
TA project focusing on Viet Nam; 
(v)  develop a long-term DRF funding strategy; 
(vi)  manage  the  two  project  selection  processes  and  present  a  report  on  final 
recommendations; 
(vii)  interface with regional departments on project selection and implementation; 
(viii)  coordinate with the implementing agency on input and collaboration with possible 
private sector partners; 
(ix)  coordinate  dissemination  of  project  data  and  results  to  stakeholders  and 
development partners; 
(x)  coordinate and participate in workshops and training programs to develop project 
design and capacity as needed; and 
(xi)  provide  regular  progress  reports  to  RSDD  and  ADB  management  on  DRF 
strategy  execution  and  develop  a  communication  and  dissemination  plan  to 
support broad awareness of project results and lessons learned, sharing the 
same with the implementing agencies.  
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

12  Appendix 3 
 
B.  Consulting Firm (6 international, 32 person-months; 8 national, 68 person-months) 
 
3.  A consultant firm or firms will work under the direction of the project coordinator, RSDD, 
and the Office of Cofinancing Operations and be responsible for project assessment, required 
risk profiling, feasibility and design, risk modeling, and project implementation and execution in 
each  DMC.  The  firm(s)  will  have  broad  specialist  knowledge  and  experience  in  DRF  and 
disaster risk management within the Asia and Pacific region as well as in insurance and capital 
markets. The technical consultants will also have, or have ready access to, specialist expertise 
in  natural  hazard  modeling,  natural  hazard  risk  assessment,  exposure  mapping,  and  loss 
modeling. It is expected that, based on its core business and expertise, a firm may subcontract 
certain components of this project. In that event, it is expected that the firm will have sufficient 
internal resources and technical experience to manage subcontractor output and be responsible 
for its content. In addition, a working knowledge of natural hazard assessment and CCA will be 
important. In the context of DRF, the technical consultants will have specialist knowledge of 
insurance, finance, and capital market products. The firm(s) will also have experience working 
with the public sector in the field of disaster risk management and preferably a sound working 
knowledge of ADB and its operations and policies. 
 
1.  National Project Facilitation (2 national, 40 person-months) 
 
4.  The consultants will  
 
(i)  maintain close coordination with and provide regular progress reports to the 
project coordinator and the implementing agency; 
(ii)  liaise closely with national staff of project partners, coordinating the implementing 
agency, cooperating agencies, and participating cities in support of the project; 
(iii)  develop and finalize the overall TA implementation plan with project partners; 
(iv)  assess,  plan,  and  implement  capacity  development  activities  with  project 
partners; 
(v)  conduct outreach activities with other interested stakeholders in the participating 
DMCs,  particularly  with  associations  of  municipalities,  civil  society,  and  the 
private sector; and 
(vi)  monitor progress toward TA objectives. 
 
2.  Risk Profiling (1 international, 3 person-months; 2 national, 4 person-months) 
 
5.  Based  on  preliminary  target  DMC  cities,  the  consultant  will  develop  risk  profiles, 
addressing  key  indicators  of  physical,  social,  and  economic  vulnerability  and  estimates  of 
potential disaster losses. 
 
3.  Risk Modeling (2 international, 16 person-months; 2 national, 14 person-months) 
 
6.  The consultants will  
 
(i)  survey  hazard,  exposure,  and  historical  loss  data  that  are  applicable  and 
available for the DMC to identify gaps; 
(ii)  use  the survey to determine the scope of new modeling work needed; 
(iii)  develop stochastic data that define hazards and potential events and address 
their potential severity and frequency; 
(iv)  develop  exposure  and  vulnerability  data  based  on  DMC  requirements  and 
specific hazards; and

14  Appendix 3 
 
(ii)  prepare  an  inception  report  on  private  market  gaps  and  imperfections  and 
potential interest in supporting ADB’s DRF activities and analyze proposed ADB 
DRF products for PPP opportunities; 
(iii)  assess the potential for an ADB catalyst role in involving the private sector in 
DRF within the region; 
(iv)  assess long-term DMC benefits from a DRF PPP strategy, including affordability; 
and 
(v)  prepare a final report on a recommended PPP DRF strategy. 
 
9.  All tasks will be carried out following the capacity development approach of this project 
to ensure sustainability and replicability after the life of the project.
